text: Moab rebelled against Israel after the death of Ahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah had fallen through the lattice of his upstairs room in Samaria, and he was injured. So he sent messengers and told them, “Go, inquire of Baal Zebub, the god of Ekron, whether I will survive this injury.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But an angel of the Lord said to Elijah from Tishbe, “Get up. Go meet the messengers of the king of Samaria and say to them, ‘Is there no God in Israel, so that you are going to seek out Baal Zebub, the god of Ekron?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord says. You will not get up from the bed you have gotten into. You will certainly die.’” So Elijah went.
speaker: Narrator

text: The messengers returned to the king, so he said to them, “Why have you come back?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, “A man came up to meet us and told us, ‘Go back to the king who sent you and tell him: This is what the Lord says. Is there no God in Israel, so that you are sending men to inquire of Baal Zebub, the god of Ekron? Therefore, you will not get up from the bed you have gotten into. You will surely die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “How would you describe the man who came up to meet you and said these words to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They told him, “He was dressed in clothing made of hair, with a leather belt tied around his waist.”
Then Ahaziah said, “That was Elijah from Tishbe!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent a captain of fifty men to Elijah. He went up to him, and there Elijah was, sitting on top of a hill. Then the captain said to him, “Man of God, the king says, ‘Come down!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah answered the captain, “If I am a man of God, let fire fall from the sky and consume you and your fifty men!” Then fire fell from the sky and consumed him and his fifty men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king sent another captain of fifty men to him, and the captain said, “Man of God, this is what the king says: ‘Come down at once!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah answered, “If I am a man of God, then let fire fall from the sky and consume you and your fifty men!” Then the fire of God fell from the sky and consumed him and his fifty men.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king sent a third captain with his fifty men. The third captain went and got down on his knees before Elijah and begged for mercy. He said to Elijah, “Man of God, let my life and the lives of these fifty servants of yours be precious in your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, fire from the sky fell and consumed the first two captains and their companies of fifty men. But now, let the lives of your servants be precious.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord said to Elijah, “Go down with him. Do not fear him.” So Elijah stood up and went down with him to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah told the king, “This is what the Lord says. Because you sent messengers to inquire of Baal Zebub, the god of Ekron—Is there no God in Israel to inquire of?—therefore, you will not get up from the bed you have gotten into. You will certainly die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he died according to the word of the Lord which Elijah had spoken. Because Ahaziah did not have a son, Jehoram became king in his place in the second year of Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat king of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Ahaziah’s acts which he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord was about to take Elijah up to heaven in a whirlwind, Elijah was traveling with Elisha from Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah said to Elisha, “Stay here, for the Lord has sent me to Bethel.”
But Elisha said, “As surely as the Lord lives and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.” So they went down to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of the prophets who were in Bethel came out to Elisha and said to him, “Do you know that today the Lord is taking your master away from you?”
Then he said, “Yes, I know. Be quiet.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elijah said to him, “Elisha, stay here because the Lord has sent me to Jericho.”
But he said, “As surely as the Lord lives and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.” So they went to Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the sons of the prophets who were in Jericho approached Elisha and said to him, “Do you know that today the Lord is taking your master away from you?”
He said, “Yes, I know. Be quiet.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elijah said to him, “Stay here because the Lord has sent me to the Jordan.”
But he said, “As surely as the Lord lives and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.” So the two of them went on.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then fifty men from the sons of the prophets came and stood and watched them from a distance, while the two of them were standing at the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah took his cloak, folded it together, and struck the water. The water divided to the right and to the left. Then the two of them crossed on dry land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they had crossed, Elijah said to Elisha, “Ask me for whatever I can do for you before I am taken from you.”
Then Elisha said, “Let there be a double portion of your spirit on me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “You have asked for a difficult thing. If you see me being taken from you, it will surely be yours. But if not, then it will not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were walking and talking, suddenly a chariot of fire and horses of fire came and separated them. So Elijah went up to heaven in a whirlwind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha was watching and crying out, “My father! My father! Israel’s chariot and its charioteers!” Then he did not see him anymore. He grabbed his clothing, and he ripped it into two pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he picked up Elijah’s cloak, which had fallen from him. He returned and stood at the edge of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took Elijah’s cloak, which had fallen from him, and he struck the water and said, “Where now is the Lord, the God of Elijah? Yes, where is he?” As soon as he struck the water, it divided to the right and to the left so that Elisha could cross.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sons of the prophets, who were watching him from Jericho, saw this, they said, “Elijah’s spirit is resting on Elisha.” They went to meet him and bowed down to the ground in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to him, “Look, here are your servants, fifty strong men. Please, let them go and search for your master in case the Spirit of the Lord lifted him up and then set him down on one of the mountains or in one of the valleys.”
But he said, “Don’t send them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they urged him to the point of embarrassment, so he said, “Send them.” So they sent the fifty men. They searched for three days, but they did not find him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they returned to Elisha, he was staying in Jericho. He said to them, “Didn’t I say to you, ‘Don’t go’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of the city said to Elisha, “Look, the site of the city is good, as my lord can see, but the water is bad, and the land deprives people of children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said, “Bring me a new dish and put salt in it.” So they brought it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went out to the spring and threw the salt in. He said, “This is what the Lord says. I have healed this water. No longer will death or loss of children come from it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the water has remained healed to this day, according to the word which Elisha spoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went up from there to Bethel. While he was going up on the road, young boys came out from the city and mocked him. They said, “Go up, baldy! Go up, baldy!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he turned around and looked at them and cursed them in the name of the Lord. Then two female bears came out of the woods, and they tore forty-two boys to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there Elisha went to Mount Carmel, and then he returned to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jehoram son of Ahab became king over Israel in Samaria in the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and he ruled as king for twelve years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord but not as his father and mother had done. He removed the sacred memorial stones for Baal which his father had made,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he clung to the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit. He did not turn from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mesha king of Moab raised sheep. He brought tribute to the king of Israel consisting of one hundred thousand lambs and the wool of one hundred thousand rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab died, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Jehoram went out from Samaria at that time, and he mobilized all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent a message to Jehoshaphat king of Judah: “Moab has rebelled against me. Will you go with me to wage war against Moab?”
Jehoshaphat replied, “I will go with you. I am like you. My people are like your people. My horses are like your horses.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jehoshaphat asked, “By what road should we go up?”
Jehoram answered, “By the road through the wilderness of Edom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel, the king of Judah, and the king of Edom marched for seven days by a roundabout way. There was no water for the army or for the animals which were along with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel said, “This is terrible! The Lord has summoned these three kings to give them into the hand of Moab!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Jehoshaphat said, “Is there no prophet of the Lord here, so that we may inquire of the Lord through him?”
One of the servants of the king of Israel answered, “Elisha son of Shaphat, who used to pour water on the hands of Elijah, is here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoshaphat said, “The word of the Lord is in him.” So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat and the king of Edom went down to meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha said to the king of Israel, “What do we have in common? Go to your father’s prophets and your mother’s prophets!”
Then the king of Israel said to him, “No, for the Lord has summoned these three kings to give them into the hand of Moab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said, “As surely as the Lord of Armies lives, before whom I stand, if I did not respect the presence of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, I would not look at you or notice you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now bring me a musician.”
While the musician was playing, the hand of the Lord came upon Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “This is what the Lord says. Make this valley full of ditches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, this is what the Lord says: You will not see wind. You will not see rain. But this valley will be full of water and you will drink—you and your livestock and your animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is nothing in the eyes of the Lord. He will also give Moab into your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will destroy all their fortified cities and all their main towns. You will cut down every good tree. You will stop up every spring of water. You will ruin every good plot of land with stones.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning, at the time for the regular offering, suddenly there was water coming from the direction of Edom. So the land was full of water.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Moab heard that the kings had come up to fight against them. They summoned all those who were old enough to strap on a sword and took their stand at the border.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up early in the morning as the rising sun was shining on the water. When the Moabites saw the water from a distance, it was red like blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Look! Blood! The kings fought and killed each other. Now, get to the plunder, Moab!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went to Israel’s camp, but Israel rose up and struck Moab, and the Moabites fled from them. Israel advanced against them to strike down Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel tore down the cities. Each man threw a stone on every good plot of land and covered all of them. They stopped up every spring, and they cut down every good tree. Only in Kir Hareseth were the stones left standing. Then the troops armed with slings surrounded it and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Moab saw that he was losing the battle, he took seven hundred swordsmen to break through to the king of Edom, but they were not able to do it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took his firstborn son, who would have become king in his place, and he offered him as a burnt offering on the wall. There was great anger against Israel, so they withdrew from him and returned to their own country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wife of one of the sons of the prophets cried out to Elisha, “Your servant, my husband, is dead. You know that your servant feared the Lord. But now the moneylender is coming to take my two sons as slaves.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elisha said to her, “What can I do for you? Tell me, what do you have in your house?”
She said, “Your servant has nothing at all in the house except a jar of olive oil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told her, “Go and ask all your neighbors for jars—empty jars. Don’t ask for only a few.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go inside and shut the door behind you and your sons. Then pour oil into all the jars. When each one is full, set it aside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she went and shut the door to her house behind her and her sons. They brought the jars, and she poured.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a jar was filled, she said to her son, “Bring me another jar.”
Finally he said, “There aren’t any more.” Then the oil stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she went and told the man of God. He said, “Go and sell the oil and pay your debt. Then you and your sons can live off what’s left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Elisha went to Shunem. A wealthy woman lived there, and she urged him to eat a meal with her. So whenever he passed by, he would stop there for a meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said to her husband, “Listen. I know that the man who passes by here all the time is a holy man of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s make a small upper room on the roof, and let’s put a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp there for him. Then whenever he comes to us, he can stay there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when Elisha came there, he went into the room and lay down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to Gehazi his servant, “Call the woman of Shunem.” He called her, and she stood in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elisha said to Gehazi, “Tell her, ‘You have been very concerned about us. What can we do for you? Is there something we can request for you from the king or from the commander of the army?’”
She said, “I am living among my own people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said, “What can be done for her?”
Then Gehazi said, “Well, she has no son, and her husband is old.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Call her.” So he called her, and she stood at the doorway.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said to her, “At this time next year, you will be holding a son.”
But she said, “No, my lord, you man of God. Do not deceive your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman conceived, and she gave birth to a son at that same time of year, just as Elisha said to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boy grew up, and one day he went out to his father, who was with the reapers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said to his father, “My head! My head!”
His father said to his servant, “Carry him to his mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he picked him up and carried him to his mother, and the boy sat on her lap until noon. Then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she went up and laid him on the bed of the man of God. She shut the door behind her and went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she called to her husband and said, “Send one of the servants to me with one of the donkeys, so that I can run to the man of God and come back.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “Why are you going to him today? It’s not the new moon, and it’s not the Sabbath.”
But she said, “It’s all right.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she saddled the donkey and said to her servant, “Lead the way. Don’t slow down for me unless I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So she went to the man of God at Mount Carmel.
When the man of God saw her from a distance, he said to his servant Gehazi, “Look! That’s the woman from Shunem!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now run to meet her and say, ‘Are you all right? Is your husband all right? Is your son all right?’”
She answered, “We’re all right.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she came to the man of God at the mountain, and she grasped his feet. Gehazi stepped forward to push her away, but the man of God said, “Leave her alone, for her soul is in distress, but the Lord has hidden it from me. He has not told me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said, “Did I ask my lord for a son? Didn’t I say, ‘Don’t give me false hope’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said to Gehazi, “Hike up your garments for travel, and take my staff in your hand and go! If you meet someone, do not greet him, and if someone greets you, do not answer. Put my staff on the boy’s face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the boy’s mother said, “As surely as the Lord lives and your soul lives, I will not leave you.” So he got up and followed her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gehazi went ahead of them and put the staff on the boy’s face. But there was no sound, and there was no response. So he went back to Elisha and told him, “The boy did not wake up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha came to the house, there the boy was—dead, lying on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went in and he shut the door behind the two of them. Then he prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He got up and lay down on top of the boy. He put his mouth to the boy’s mouth, his eyes to the boy’s eyes, his palms to the boy’s palms. Then he bent down over him, and the boy’s flesh became warm.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went back into the house and paced back and forth. Then he went up and bent down over him, and the boy sneezed seven times. Then the boy opened his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha called Gehazi and said, “Call the woman of Shunem!” So he called her, and she came in. He said, “Pick up your son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she came in and fell at Elisha’s feet and bowed down to the ground. Then she picked up her son and went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha returned to Gilgal. There was a famine in the land. The sons of the prophets were sitting with him, and he said to his servant, “Put the large cooking pot on the fire, and cook some stew for the sons of the prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the men went out to the field to gather plants. He found a wild vine and picked some gourds from it. He filled his garment with them. Then he came in and cut them into pieces for the pot of stew. They did not know what they were,
speaker: Narrator

text: but they served it to the men to eat. While they were eating the stew, they cried out, “Man of God, there is death in the pot!” So they could not eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “Take some flour and throw it into the pot.” Then he said, “Serve it to the people.” They ate, and there was nothing harmful in the pot.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man came from Baal Shalishah and brought the man of God some bread from the first ripe grain, twenty loaves of barley bread, and some new grain in his sack. Elisha said, “Set it before the people so that they can eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His attendant said, “How can I set this before one hundred men?” But he said, “Set it before the people so that they may eat, for this is what the Lord says: They will eat and have some left over.” So he set it before them. They ate, and they had some left over, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Na’aman, the commander of the king of Aram’s army, was a great man in the opinion of his master. He was highly honored because the Lord had provided victory for Aram through him. Although he was a powerful warrior, he had leprosy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Raiding parties had once gone out from Aram and brought back a young girl. She served Na’aman’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to her mistress, “I wish my master stood before the prophet who is in Samaria, because he would cure him of his leprosy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Na’aman went and told his master what the servant girl from the land of Israel had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Aram said, “Go there. I will send a letter to the king of Israel.” So Na’aman went, and he took ten talents of silver and six thousand shekels of gold and ten sets of clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took the letter to the king of Israel. The letter said, “Now, when you receive this letter, you will know that I am sending my officer Na’aman to you so that you can cure him of his leprosy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel read the letter, he tore his clothing and said, “Am I God that I can kill and make alive? Why is he sending a man to me for me to heal him from his leprosy? See how he is looking for a pretext to fight against me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent a message to the king: “Why have you torn your clothes? Let him come to me, and he will know that there is a prophet in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Na’aman went with his horses and chariots and stopped in front of the door of Elisha’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha sent a messenger out to him to say, “Go and wash seven times in the Jordan. Then your flesh will be restored and you will be clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Na’aman was angry and he left, saying, “Look, I said to myself, ‘He will certainly come out and stand and call on the name of the Lord his God and wave his hand over the place, and I will be cured of the leprosy!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Aren’t the Abana and the Pharpar, the rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? Couldn’t I wash in them and be cleansed?” So he turned and went away in a burning rage.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his servants approached and spoke to him. They said, “My father, if the prophet had told you to do some great thing, would you not do it? How much more when he says to you, ‘Wash and be clean’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went down and dipped in the Jordan seven times, just as the man of God had said. Then his flesh was restored like the flesh of a small child, and he was clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he and his whole escort went back to the man of God. He stood in front of Elisha and said, “To be sure, now I know that there is no God in all the earth except in Israel. Now accept a gift from your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha said, “As surely as the Lord lives, in whose presence I stand, I will not take anything.” Even though Na’aman urged him to accept something, he refused.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Na’aman said, “If you do not want anything, please give me, your servant, as much dirt as two donkeys can carry, for your servant will never again burn incense or sacrifice to other gods, but only to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But may the Lord forgive your servant this one thing: When my master goes into the house of Rimmon to bow down there and he supports himself on my arm, then I too have to bow down in the house of Rimmon. When I bow down in the house of Rimmon, may the Lord forgive your servant this one thing.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elisha said to him, “Go in peace.”
When Na’aman had gone some distance from him,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gehazi, the servant of Elisha the man of God, said, “My master was too easy on this Aramean, Na’aman, when he did not accept anything that he brought. As surely as the Lord lives, I will run after him and get something from him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gehazi chased after Na’aman. When Na’aman saw him running after him, he got down from his chariot to meet him. He said, “Is everything all right?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gehazi said, “Yes, everything is all right. My master sent me to say, ‘Look, just now two young men from the hill country of Ephraim, from the sons of the prophets, have come to me. Please give them a talent of silver and two sets of clothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Na’aman said, “Certainly! Take two talents!” He urged Gehazi and tied up the two talents of silver in two bags with the two sets of clothing. Then Na’aman gave them to his two servants, and they carried them ahead of Gehazi.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came to the hill, he took the gifts from them. Then he hid them in the house and sent the men back, so they left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he went in and attended his master.
Elisha said to him, “Where were you, Gehazi?”
Gehazi said, “Your servant didn’t go anywhere.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said to him, “Didn’t my heart go along when the man got down from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time to take silver, or to accept clothing or olive groves or vineyards or sheep or cattle or male and female servants?
speaker: Narrator

text: Na’aman’s leprosy will cling to you and to your descendants forever.” Then Gehazi went out from his presence, leprous like snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of the prophets said to Elisha, “Look, the place where we are living with you is too cramped for us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let’s go to the Jordan, and every one of us will get a wooden beam from there so we can build a place there for us to live.”
He said, “Go ahead.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then one of them said, “Won’t you also please come along with your servants?”
He said, “I will come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went with them. When they came to the Jordan, they began to cut down trees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But while one of them was cutting down a tree for a beam, the ax fell into the water.
He cried out, “Oh no, my lord! It was borrowed!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man of God said, “Where did it fall?” Then he showed him the place. He cut off a piece of wood and threw it into the water, and the ax floated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Pick it up.” So he reached out his hand and took it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the king of Aram was waging war against Israel, he would make plans with his officials, saying, “My camp will be at such and such a place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man of God would send a message to the king of Israel, saying, “Be careful when you pass this place because the Arameans are going down there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel would send scouts to the place that the man of God had pointed out. So the man of God warned him, and he was kept safe—and not just once or twice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Aram was enraged because of this. He summoned his officials and said to them, “Won’t you tell me who of us is for the king of Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of his officials said, “No, my lord the king. It is Elisha, the prophet in Israel, who tells the king of Israel the words which you speak in your bedroom.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said, “Go and see where he is. Then I’ll send men and capture him.”
He was told, “Dothan is where he is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent horses and chariots and a strong force there. They came at night and surrounded the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man of God’s servant got up early and went out, there were soldiers, horses, and chariots surrounding the city. So his attendant said to Elisha, “Oh no, my lord! What will we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “Don’t be afraid, for those who are with us are more than those who are with them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha prayed and said, “O Lord, open his eyes so that he can see.” Then the Lord opened the servant’s eyes, and he saw that the hills were full of horses and chariots of fire, all around Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Arameans came down, Elisha prayed to the Lord, “Strike these people with blindness.” So he struck them with blindness, just as Elisha had asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said to them, “This is not the road, and this is not the city. Follow me, and I will take you to the man you are looking for.” So he brought them to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came into Samaria, Elisha prayed, “O Lord, open their eyes so that they can see.” Then the Lord opened their eyes, and they saw that they were right in the middle of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel saw them, he said to Elisha, “Shall I strike them down, my father? Shall I strike them down?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Do not strike them down. Would you strike down a man you captured with your own sword and bow? Set food and water before them so that they can eat and drink and then go back to their master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he gave a great feast for them. They ate and drank. Then he sent them on their way, and they went to their master. The Aramean raiding parties did not come into the land of Israel anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: After these things, Ben Hadad king of Aram mobilized his whole army and went up and laid siege to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a severe famine in Samaria, because the siege lasted until a donkey head sold for eighty shekels of silver and a cup of dove’s droppings for five shekels of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel was walking on the wall, a woman cried out to him, “Help me, my lord the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “If the Lord does not help you, where can I get help for you? From the threshing floor or from the winepress?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king asked her, “What is the problem?”
She said, “This woman said to me, ‘Come on, give up your son, and we will eat him today, and we will eat my son tomorrow.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So we cooked my son and ate him. Then I said to her the next day, ‘Give up your son so that we may eat him,’ but she hid her son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard the woman’s words, he tore his clothes. As he was walking on the wall, the people were surprised to see that he was wearing sackcloth on his body, underneath his clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “May God punish me severely and even double it, if the head of Elisha son of Shaphat remains on his shoulders today!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. The king sent a man ahead of him. But before the messenger came to him, Elisha said to the elders, “Do you see that this murderer has sent this man to cut off my head? When the messenger comes, shut the door and push against it. Isn’t the sound of the feet of his master behind him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking with them, the messenger came down to him. Then the king said, “Indeed this evil is from the Lord. Why should I wait hopefully for the Lord anymore?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said, “All of you, hear the word of the Lord! This is what the Lord says. At this time tomorrow at the gate of Samaria, twelve pounds of fine flour will sell for a shekel and twenty-four pounds of barley for a shekel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the officer at the king’s right hand, on whose arm the king was leaning, answered the man of God, “Really? Even if the Lord opened the windows of heaven, could this happen?”
Elisha said, “Listen to me. You yourself will see it with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now four lepers were at the entrance to the gate. They said to each other, “Why should we sit here until we die?
speaker: Narrator

text: If we say, ‘Let’s go into the city,’ there is famine in the city and we will die there. But if we stay here, we will die. So let’s go over to the camp of the Arameans. If they let us live, we will live. If they kill us, we will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they got up at twilight to go to the camp of the Arameans. When they reached the edge of the camp of the Arameans, they saw that there was no one there!
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had caused the Arameans to hear the sound of horses and chariots and the sound of a great army. They said to each other, “Listen! The king of Israel has hired the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Egypt to come against us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they arose and fled at twilight. They left their tents, their horses, and their donkeys in the camp just as they were, and they fled for their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when these lepers came to the edge of the camp, they went into a tent, and they ate and drank. They picked up silver, gold, and clothing and went and hid it. Then they returned and went to another tent. They took some of what was there and went and hid it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said to each other, “We should not be doing this. Today is a day of good news, and we are keeping silent. If we wait until daylight, our sin will find us. So come on, let’s go and tell about this at the king’s palace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went and called out to the city gatekeepers and told them, “We went into the camp of the Arameans, and we looked, but there was no one there! Not even the sound of a man! But the horses and the donkeys are tied there, and the tents are just as they were!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the gatekeepers proclaimed the news, and it was reported in the king’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king got up at night and said to his officials, “I’ll tell you what the Arameans are doing to us: They know that we are hungry so they left the camp to hide in the fields, saying, ‘They will certainly come out of the city, and we will capture them alive. Then we’ll get into the city!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But one of his officials answered, “Please let some men take five of the horses that are left in the city—look, they won’t be any worse off than all the rest of the Israelites who are left here—all the other Israelites who are about to die. Let’s send them out, and let’s see.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took two chariots with their horses, and the king sent them after the army of Aram, saying, “Go and take a look.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they followed them to the Jordan. The whole road was full of clothing and equipment that the Arameans threw away while they fled in panic. Then the messengers returned and reported to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people went out and looted the Aramean camp. So twelve pounds of fine flour sold for a shekel and twenty-four pounds of barley for a shekel, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king appointed the officer on whose arm he leaned to be in charge of the gate. But the people trampled him in the gate, and he died, just as the man of God had said when the king went down to speak to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It happened just as the man of God had said to the king: “Twenty-four pounds of barley will be sold for a shekel and twelve pounds of fine flour for a shekel by this time tomorrow in the gate of Samaria.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The officer had said to the man of God, “Really? Even if the Lord opened the windows of heaven, could something like this happen?”
The man of God had said, “Listen to me. You yourself will see it with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all this happened to him just like that: The people trampled him in the gate and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha said to the woman whose son he had brought back to life, “You and your household, make preparations and leave, and stay in whatever other country you can, for the Lord has decreed a famine that will be in the land for seven years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the woman got up and did just as the man of God said. She and her household went and lived in the land of the Philistines for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of seven years, the woman returned from the land of the Philistines. Then she went to appeal to the king to get back her house and her fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king had told Gehazi, the servant of the man of God, “Tell me all the great things which Elisha has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was telling the king how Elisha had brought the dead boy back to life, the very woman whose son he had brought back to life was coming to appeal to the king about her house and her fields. Then Gehazi said, “My lord the king, this is the woman, and this is her son whom Elisha brought back to life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king asked the woman about it, and she told him. So the king appointed a high official to her case, saying, “Return everything which is hers and all the produce of her fields, from the day she left the land until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha went to Damascus while Ben Hadad the king of Aram was sick. The king was told, “The man of God has come here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king said to Hazael, “Take a gift and go to meet the man of God. You will inquire of the Lord through him, asking whether I will survive this sickness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazael went to meet him. He took a gift of forty camel loads of all the goods of Damascus, and he came and stood before Elisha and said, “Your son, Ben Hadad, king of Aram, sent me to you to say, ‘Will I survive this sickness?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said to him, “Go and say to him, ‘You will certainly survive,’ but the Lord has shown me that he will really die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha stared straight at him until Hazael was embarrassed. Then the man of God wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hazael said, “Why is my lord weeping?”
Then he said, “Because I know the evil you will do to the people of Israel. You will set fire to their fortified cities. You will kill their young men with the sword. You will dash their children to pieces, and you will rip open their pregnant women.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Hazael said, “But what is your servant, a mere dog, that he could do such a great thing?”
Then Elisha said, “The Lord has shown me that you will be king over Aram.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hazael then left Elisha and went to his master, and the king said to him, “What did Elisha say to you?”
He said, “He told me that you will certainly survive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the next day, he took a thick cloth, dipped it in water, and spread it on the king’s face so that he died. Then Hazael became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth year of Joram son of Ahab, the king of Israel, while Jehoshaphat was king of Judah, Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he was king for eight years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in the way of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Ahab did, because the daughter of Ahab was his wife. So he did evil in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for the sake of his servant David, the Lord was not willing to destroy Judah, because he had said that he would give a lamp to David and to his sons forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: During his days, Edom broke away from the control of Judah and set a king over themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joram crossed over to Zair with all his chariots. At night he rose up and attacked the Edomites who had surrounded him and his chariot commanders, but his army fled to their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Edom has been in revolt against Judah to this day. Libnah also rebelled at the same time.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Joram’s acts and everything he did, are they not written in the Book of the Annals the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: Joram rested with his fathers, and he was buried with his fathers in the City of David. Then his son Ahaziah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year of Joram son of Ahab king of Israel, Ahaziah son of Jehoram king of Judah became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he ruled as king in Jerusalem for one year. His mother’s name was Athaliah, granddaughter of Omri, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in the way of the house of Ahab and did evil in the eyes of the Lord, just as the house of Ahab had done, because he was a son-in-law of the house of Ahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went with Joram son of Ahab to wage war against Hazael king of Aram at Ramoth Gilead. The Arameans wounded Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Joram returned to Jezre’el to recover from the wounds which the Arameans inflicted on him at Ramoth Gilead when he fought against Hazael king of Aram. So Ahaziah son of Jehoram king of Judah went down to see Joram son of Ahab in Jezre’el because he had been wounded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha called one of the sons of the prophets and told him, “Hike up your garments for travel, and take this flask of oil in your hand and go to Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you get there, look for Jehu son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi. Go in and have him excuse himself from his associates and bring him into an inner room.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the flask of oil, pour it out on his head, and say, ‘This is what the Lord says. I anoint you king over Israel.’ Then open the door and flee. Do not delay!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the young man, the servant of the prophet, went to Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he got there, he found the commanders of the army sitting together.
He said, “I have a message for you, commander.”
Then Jehu said, “For which of us?”
He answered, “For you, commander.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu got up and went into the house. Then the servant poured the oil on his head and said, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says. I anoint you king over the Lord’s people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will strike down the house of your master Ahab, and I will avenge the blood of my servants the prophets and the blood of all the servants of the Lord that was shed by Jezebel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole house of Ahab will perish. In Israel I will cut off from Ahab those who urinate against the wall, both bound and free.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the house of Ahab like the house of Jeroboam son of Nebat and like the house of Ba’asha son of Ahijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The dogs will eat Jezebel on the plot of ground in Jezre’el, and no one will bury her.” Then he opened the door and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jehu went out to the rest of the king’s officers. They said to him, “Is everything all right? Why did that madman come to you?”
He said to them, “You know the man and how he talks.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they said, “That’s not true! Tell us!”
So he said, “He told me this and that, and then he said, ‘This is what the Lord says. I anoint you king over Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Each man quickly took his cloak. Then they placed them under him on the bare steps. Then they blew the ram’s horn and said, “Jehu is king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu, the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi, conspired against Joram. Now Joram and all Israel had been guarding Ramoth Gilead against Hazael king of Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But King Joram returned to Jezre’el to recover from the wounds which the Arameans had inflicted on him when he fought against Hazael king of Aram.
Then Jehu said, “If you really want me to be king, don’t let any survivors get out of the city to go and report in Jezre’el.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu got in his chariot and went to Jezre’el, because Joram was resting there and Ahaziah king of Judah had gone down to see Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now the watchman was standing on the tower in Jezre’el, and he saw Jehu’s troops coming, so the watchman said, “I see a large group coming!”
Then Joram said, “Get a rider and send him to meet them and say, ‘Do you come in peace?’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So a horseman went to meet him. He said, “This is what the king says. Do you come in peace?”
Then Jehu said, “What do you have to do with peace? Fall in behind me.”
Then the watchmen said, “The messenger reached him but did not return.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he sent a second horseman. He came to them and said, “This is what the king says. Do you come in peace?”
Jehu answered, “What do you have to do with peace? Fall in behind me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the watchman said, “He reached them, but he did not return. But the driving is like Jehu son of Nimshi’s driving. He drives like a madman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joram said, “Hitch up a chariot!” Then they hitched up his chariot, and Joram king of Israel and Ahaziah king of Judah went out, each in his own chariot, to meet Jehu. They reached him at the plot of ground that had belonged to Naboth from Jezre’el.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Joram saw Jehu, he said, “Do you come in peace, Jehu?”
Jehu answered, “What peace can there be as long as so much of your mother Jezebel’s prostitution and witchcraft exists?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joram turned his chariot around and fled. He said to Ahaziah, “Treachery, Ahaziah!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu drew his bow and shot Joram between his shoulders. The arrow pierced his heart, and he slumped down in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu said to Bidkar, his chariot officer, “Pick him up and throw him onto the plot of land that belonged to Naboth from Jezre’el. Remember that when you and I were riding side by side in chariots behind his father Ahab, the Lord made this pronouncement against him:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As surely as I saw the blood of Naboth and the blood of his sons yesterday, the Lord declares, I will repay you on this plot of land, the Lord declares.’ So now, pick him up and throw him onto that plot of land according to the word of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah king of Judah saw this and fled on the road toward Beth Hagan. But Jehu pursued him and said, “Shoot him too!” They shot him in his chariot on the way up to Gur, that is Ibleam. Then he fled to Megiddo and died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants brought him in his chariot to Jerusalem and buried him in his own tomb with his fathers in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: (It was in the eleventh year of Joram son of King Ahab that Ahaziah had become king over Judah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu went to Jezre’el. When Jezebel heard it, she put on eye make-up and arranged her hair. Then she looked down through a window.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu came into the gate, she said, “Do you come in peace, Zimri, the killer of your master?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked up to the window and said, “Who is with me? Who?” Two or three eunuchs looked down to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Throw her down!” So they threw her down, and her blood splattered on the wall and on the horses, and they trampled her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went inside and ate and drank. Then Jehu said, “See to that cursed woman and bury her, because she was a king’s daughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they went to bury her, they did not find her, except for her skull, her feet, and the palms of her hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came back and told him. Then Jehu said, “This is the word of the Lord which he spoke through his servant Elijah from Tishbe: On the plot of ground at Jezre’el, the dogs will eat the flesh of Jezebel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jezebel’s corpse will be like manure spread on the surface of the field at the plot of ground at Jezre’el, so they won’t be able to say, ‘This is Jezebel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab had seventy sons in Samaria, so Jehu wrote letters and sent them to Samaria, that is, to the officials of Samaria, the elders, and to the guardians appointed by Ahab, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, when this letter comes to you, since you have your master’s sons with you and you have chariots, horses, a fortified city, and weapons,
speaker: Narrator

text: choose the best and most upright of your master’s sons and seat him on his father’s throne and fight for your master’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They were terrified and said, “Look, two kings could not stand before him, so how can we?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the palace administrator, the ruler of the city, the elders, and the guardians sent word to Jehu, saying, “We are your servants. We will do everything you tell us. We will not make any man king. Do whatever is good in your eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jehu wrote a second letter to them, saying, “If you are on my side and will obey me, then take the heads of your master’s sons and come to me at this time tomorrow in Jezre’el.”
Now the king’s seventy sons were with the leaders of the city who were raising them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the letter came, they took the king’s sons and slaughtered all seventy of them. Then they put their heads in baskets and sent them to Jehu in Jezre’el.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messenger arrived, he said, “They have brought the heads of the king’s sons.” Jehu said, “Put them in two piles at the entrance to the gate until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When morning came, he went out and stood and said to all the people, “You are innocent. Indeed I conspired against my master and killed him. But who killed all these?
speaker: Narrator

text: Know, therefore, that nothing of the word of the Lord, which the Lord spoke against the house of Ahab, will fail. For the Lord did what he said through his servant Elijah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu killed everyone who remained from the house of Ahab in Jezre’el and all his important people, his close friends, and his priests, so that no survivor was left to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he set out toward Samaria. While he was on the way, at Beth Eked of the Shepherds,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu met some relatives of Ahaziah king of Judah. He said, “Who are you?” They said, “We are Ahaziah’s relatives. We have come down to greet the king’s sons and the queen mother’s sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Take them alive!” So they took them. Then they slaughtered them at the cistern of Beth Eked—forty-two men, and he did not let one survive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he set out from there and met Jehonadab son of Recab, who was coming to meet him. Jehu greeted him and said, “Is your heart as true to my heart as my heart is to yours?”
He said, “It is.”
Then Jehu said, “If it is, then give me your hand!” So Jehonadab gave him his hand, and Jehu helped him up into the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu said, “Come with me and see my zeal for the Lord.” So he had him ride with him in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came to Samaria, he struck down everyone who was left to Ahab there. He wiped out Ahab completely, according to the word which the Lord had spoken to Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu assembled all the people and said to them, “Ahab served Baal a little. Jehu will serve him a great deal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now, gather all the prophets of Baal, all his servants, and all his priests! Let no one be missing because I am going to make a great sacrifice to Baal. No one who misses it will live.”
But Jehu was acting deceptively in order to exterminate the servants of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu said, “Consecrate a festival for Baal,” and they proclaimed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu sent word through all Israel, and all the servants of Baal came. Not a man was left who did not come. They came into the temple of Baal so that the temple of Baal was filled from end to end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to the person in charge of the wardrobe, “Bring out garments for all the servants of Baal.” So he brought out robes for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu and Jehonadab son of Recab went into the temple of Baal. Jehu said to the servants of Baal, “Make a careful search, and see to it that there are no servants of the Lord with you, but only servants of Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went in to make sacrifices and whole burnt offerings. But Jehu had stationed eighty men outside and said, “If any man escapes from these men whom I am putting into your hands, it will be your life for his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was finished offering the whole burnt offering, Jehu said to the guards and to the officers, “Go strike them down! Don’t let anyone out!” So they struck them down with their swords, and the guards and the officers threw the bodies out. They then went into the inner sanctuary of the temple of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the sacred memorial stones out from the temple of Baal and burned them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They tore down the memorial stone for Baal and tore down the temple of Baal. They have used it for a latrine to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way Jehu exterminated Baal worship from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when it came to the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit, Jehu did not turn aside from following the golden calves which were in Bethel and in Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Jehu, “Because you have done well by doing what is right in my eyes—you have done everything that was in my heart to the house of Ahab—four generations of your sons will sit on the throne of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehu was not careful to walk in the law of the Lord, the God of Israel, with all his heart. He did not turn from the sins which Jeroboam caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, the Lord began to break off pieces from Israel. Then Hazael attacked all the territory of Israel
speaker: Narrator

text: east of the Jordan, all the land of Gilead, Gad, Reuben, and Manasseh, from Aroer, which is above the canyon of the Arnon, up to Gilead and Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Jehu’s acts and everything he did and all his mighty deeds, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu rested with his fathers, and they buried him in Samaria. Then his son Jehoahaz became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time that Jehu ruled as king over Israel in Samaria was twenty-eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Athaliah, the mother of Ahaziah, saw that her son was dead, she went into action and destroyed all the royal heirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehosheba, King Joram’s daughter and Ahaziah’s sister, took Joash, the son of Ahaziah. She stole him away from among the king’s sons, who were to be killed. She put him and his nurse in a bedroom. He was kept hidden from Athaliah so that he was not killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was kept hidden with her in the House of the Lord for six years while Athaliah was ruling over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year, Jehoiada sent a message and summoned the officers in charge of the units of the Carians and the guards to meet him at the House of the Lord. He made a covenant with them and had them swear an oath in the House of the Lord. Then he showed them the king’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He commanded them, “This is how you will deploy: A third of you who are coming on duty on the Sabbath are to guard the palace of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Another third will be stationed at the Sur Gate, and the final third at the gate behind the guards who take turns protecting this temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two divisions of you who are going off duty on the Sabbath will protect the House of the Lord, together with the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will surround the king on all sides, every man with his weapons in his hand. Anyone who comes into the ranks will be put to death. You will accompany the king when he goes out and when he comes in.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the officers of the companies did just as Jehoiada the priest commanded. Each one took his men, those coming on duty on the Sabbath with those going off duty on the Sabbath, and they came to Jehoiada the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest gave the officers in charge of the units the spears and shields which had belonged to King David and which were in the House of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the guards, each one with his weapon in his hand, stood around the king from the south side of the temple to the north side, near the altar of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoiada brought out the king’s son and set the crown on him and gave him the Testimony, and they made him king. They anointed him and clapped their hands and said, “Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Athaliah heard the noise of the guards and the people, she went to them in the House of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: She looked, and there was the king standing beside the pillar according to the custom, and the officers and the trumpeters were in front of the king, and all the people of the land were celebrating and blowing trumpets. Then Athaliah tore her clothes and cried, “Treason! Treason!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jehoiada the priest commanded the officers in charge of the units of the army, “Bring her out between the ranks! Anyone who follows her is to be put to death with the sword!”
Because the priest had said, “She is not to be killed in the House of the Lord,”
speaker: Narrator

text: they laid hands on her as she was going through the passageway where the horses enter the king’s palace, and they killed her there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoiada made a covenant between the Lord and the king and people that they would be the Lord’s people. He also made a covenant between the king and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people of the land went to the temple of Baal and tore it down. They smashed its altar and its idols till they were dust. They also killed Mattan the priest of Baal in front of the altars. Then the priest posted a watch over the House of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took the officers of the companies and the Carians and the guards and all the people of the land, and they brought the king down from the House of the Lord. They entered the king’s palace through the gate of the guards. Then he sat on the throne of the kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of the land rejoiced, and the city was quiet. Athaliah had been put to death with the sword in the king’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash was seven years old when he became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year of Jehu, Jehoash became king, and he was king in Jerusalem for forty years. His mother’s name was Zibiah from Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash did what was right in the eyes of the Lord during the whole time that Jehoiada the priest instructed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the high places were still not removed. The people were making sacrifices and burning incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash said to the priests, “All the silver from the sacred offerings which is brought into the House of the Lord—the redemption money which is assessed to each man in the census, all the money from the redemption of dedicated things, and all the money which any man brings to the House of the Lord as a gift from his heart—
speaker: Narrator

text: the priests are to take it from the donor and repair whatever damage is found in the temple.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the twenty-third year of King Jehoash, the priests had not repaired the damage to the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Jehoash summoned Jehoiada the priest and the other priests, and he said to them, “Why aren’t you repairing the damage to the temple? Do not accept any more silver from those who are handing it in to you. Instead, put it toward repairing the damage to the temple.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priests agreed that they would not take any silver from the people and that they themselves would not do the work of repairing the damage to the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoiada the priest took a box, drilled a hole in its lid, and placed it at the right side of the altar as one entered the House of the Lord. Then the priests who were guarding the threshold put all the money which came into the House of the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw that there was a large quantity of silver in the box, the king’s secretary and the high priest went up and tied it in bags and tallied the silver which was found in the House of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they gave the silver which had been weighed out to those who were overseeing the work on the House of the Lord. They paid it out to the carpenters and the builders who were working on the House of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and to the bricklayers and the stonemasons, who used it to buy wood and stone from the quarry to repair the damage to the House of the Lord and to meet all the expenses for repairing the building.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the silver basins, snuffers, sprinkling bowls, trumpets, and all the gold and silver articles for the House of the Lord were not made from this silver which was brought into the House of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather they paid it to the ones who were doing the work, and they repaired the House of the Lord with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not audit the men to whom they gave the silver to do the work, because they were acting honestly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The silver from the restitution offerings and the silver from the sin offerings was not brought into the House of the Lord. It belonged to the priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hazael king of Aram came up and attacked Gath and captured it. Hazael turned to go up against Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoash king of Judah took all the sacred articles which his fathers Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, kings of Judah, had dedicated, as well as the sacred articles that he himself had given and all the gold which was found in the treasuries of the House of the Lord and in the king’s palace, and he sent them to Hazael king of Aram. So Hazael left Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of the acts of Jehoash and all the things he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants conspired against him and killed Jehoash at Beth Millo, along the road down to Silla.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants Jozabad son of Shimath and Jehozabad son of Shomer struck him down, and he died. They buried him with his fathers in the City of David. Then his son Amaziah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-third year of Joash son of Ahaziah, king of Judah, Jehoahaz son of Jehu became king over Israel in Samaria for seventeen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He walked in the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit. He did not turn from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s anger burned against Israel, so he gave them into the hand of Hazael king of Aram and into the hand of Ben Hadad son of Hazael, all his days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz, however, sought the Lord’s favor, and the Lord listened to him, because he saw the oppression that the king of Aram was inflicting on Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord appointed a deliverer for Israel, and they escaped from the power of the Arameans. Then the people of Israel lived in their own homes as they had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not turn from the sins which the house of Jeroboam caused Israel to commit. They walked in them, and there was even an Asherah pole standing in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nothing was left of Jehoahaz’s army except fifty charioteers, ten chariots, and ten thousand foot soldiers, for the king of Aram had destroyed them. He made them like dust at threshing time.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of the acts of Jehoahaz and everything he did and his mighty deeds, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz rested with his fathers and they buried him in Samaria. Then his son Joash became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-seventh year of Joash king of Judah, Jehoash son of Jehoahaz became king over Israel in Samaria for sixteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He did not turn from all the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit. He walked in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Joash’s acts and all he did and his mighty deeds, how he fought with Amaziah king of Judah, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash rested with his fathers. Then Jeroboam sat on his throne. Joash was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha was suffering from the illness from which he would die, and Joash king of Israel went down to him. Then he wept over him and said, “My father! My father! Israel’s chariot and its charioteers!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said to him, “Get a bow and arrow.” So he brought a bow and arrow to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told the king of Israel, “Take the bow in your hands!” So he took the bow in his hands. Then Elisha put his hand on the king’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “Open the window to the east.” So he opened it.
Then Elisha said, “Shoot!” So he shot.
Then he said, “The arrow of victory for the Lord! The arrow of victory over Aram! You will completely destroy Aram at Aphek!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elisha said, “Take your arrows.” So he took the arrows.
Then he said to the king of Israel, “Strike the ground!” So he struck it three times and then stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man of God was furious with him and said, “You should have struck the ground five or six times! Then you would have completely destroyed Aram. But now, you will defeat Aram only three times.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elisha died, and they buried him.
Now raiders from Moab were coming into the land during the spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: While a man was being buried, the people suddenly saw the raiders, so they threw the man into the tomb of Elisha. When the man touched the bones of Elisha, he came to life, and he got up on his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazael king of Aram had oppressed Israel all the days of Jehoahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was gracious to them and showed compassion for them, and he turned his attention to them because of his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. So until this time he has not been willing to destroy them, nor did he cast them from his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hazael king of Aram died, and his son Ben Hadad became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash son of Jehoahaz took action and recovered from Ben Hadad son of Hazael the cities which Hazael had taken from his father Jehoahaz in war. Three times Joash defeated him and recovered those Israelite cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year of Joash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel, Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he ruled for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jehoaddin from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, but not like his father David. He did everything his father Joash had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the high places were still not removed. The people were still offering sacrifices and burning incense at the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the royal power was firmly in his hand, he killed his officials who had killed his father the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not put the sons of the assassins to death, in obedience to what is written in the Book of the Law of Moses, in which the Lord commanded, “Fathers are not to be put to death on account of their sons, and sons are not to be put to death on account of their fathers, but each person will die for his own sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck down ten thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt. He seized Sela in the war and named it Jokthe’el, the name it has to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, son of Jehu, king of Israel, saying, “Come, let’s confront each other face-to-face.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jehoash king of Israel sent a message to Amaziah king of Judah:
A thornbush in Lebanon sent a message to a cedar in Lebanon, saying, “Give your daughter to my son as his wife.” But a wild animal in Lebanon passed by and trampled the thornbush.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have indeed defeated Edom, and your heart has become proud. Accept that honor and remain in your palace. Why stir up disaster so that you fall, and Judah falls with you?
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amaziah did not listen, so Jehoash king of Israel attacked. He and Amaziah king of Judah confronted each other face-to-face at Beth Shemesh, which belongs to Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah was defeated by Israel, and each man fled to his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash king of Israel captured Amaziah son of Jehoash, son of Ahaziah, king of Judah, at Beth Shemesh. Then they went to Jerusalem. Jehoash broke down six hundred feet of the wall of Jerusalem from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took all the gold and silver, all the articles found in the house of the Lord and in the treasuries of the king’s palace. He also took hostages and returned to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Jehoash’s acts, the things he did and his mighty deeds, and how he fought with Amaziah king of Judah, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash rested with his fathers and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. Then his son Jeroboam became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah lived for fifteen years after the death of Jehoash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Amaziah’s acts, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: A conspiracy was raised against him in Jerusalem, so he fled to Lachish. But they sent men after him to Lachish and killed him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they brought him back on horses and buried him in Jerusalem with his fathers in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people of Judah took Azariah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was he who built Elat and restored it to Judah after King Amaziah rested with his fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifteenth year of Amaziah son of Joash, king of Judah, Jeroboam son of Joash, king of Israel, became king in Samaria for forty-one years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He did not turn from all the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was he who restored the boundary of Israel from Lebo Hamath to the Dead Sea according to the word which the Lord, the God of Israel, had spoken through his servant, the prophet Jonah son of Amittai, who was from Gath Hepher.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord saw the misery of Israel, which was extremely bitter for both bound and free. There was no one to help Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the Lord had not said that he would wipe the name of Israel from under the heavens, he rescued them by the hand of Jeroboam son of Joash.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Jeroboam’s acts and everything he did and his mighty deeds, the wars he fought, and how he recovered Damascus and Hamath (which had belonged to Judah) for Israel, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam rested with his fathers, the kings of Israel. Then his son Zechariah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-seventh year of Jeroboam king of Israel, Azariah son of Amaziah king of Judah became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was sixteen years old when he became king, and he ruled for fifty-two years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jekoliah from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, like everything that his father Amaziah had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high places were still not removed. The people were still offering sacrifices and burning incense there at the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord afflicted the king so that he had leprosy until the day of his death. So he lived in a quarantined house, and Jotham, the king’s son, was in charge of the palace and administered justice for the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Azariah’s acts and everything he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah rested with his fathers, and he was buried in the City of David. Then his son Jotham became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-eighth year of Azariah king of Judah, Zechariah son of Jeroboam ruled as king over Israel in Samaria for six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, just as his fathers had done. He did not turn from the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum son of Jabesh conspired against him. He struck him down in front of the people and killed him. Then he became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Zechariah’s acts, you can find them written in the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the word of the Lord which he had spoken to Jehu: “Four generations of your sons will sit on the throne of Israel.” And that is what happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum son of Jabesh became king in the thirty-ninth year of Uzziah king of Judah, and he ruled for one month in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Menahem son of Gadi from Tirzah went up to Samaria. He struck down Shallum son of Jabesh in Samaria and killed him. Then he became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Shallum’s acts, including the conspiracy he led, you can find written in the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Menahem, starting from Tirzah, attacked Tiphsah and all the people who were in it and its territory. Because they did not open their gates to him, he attacked it and cut open every pregnant woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-ninth year of Azariah king of Judah, Menahem son of Gadi became king over Israel in Samaria and ruled for ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord. All his days he did not turn from the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pul king of Assyria came against the land, and Menahem gave Pul one thousand talents of silver for supporting him and strengthening his hold over the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Menahem exacted the silver from Israel, from every wealthy man—fifty shekels from each man—to give to the king of Assyria. Then the king of Assyria left. He did not remain in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Menahem’s acts and everything he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Menahem rested with his fathers. Then his son Pekahiah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fiftieth year of Azariah king of Judah, Pekahiah son of Menahem became king over Israel in Samaria for two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He did not turn from the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pekah son of Remaliah, his military advisor, conspired against him and struck him down in the fortified part of the king’s palace in Samaria, along with Argob and Arieh. Fifty men from Gilead were with Pekah when he killed Pekahiah and became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Pekahiah’s acts and everything he did, you can find them written in the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifty-second year of Azariah king of Judah, Pekah son of Remaliah became king over Israel in Samaria and ruled for twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He did not turn from the sins which Jeroboam son of Nebat caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days of Pekah king of Israel, Tiglath Pileser king of Assyria came and took Ijon, Abel Beth Ma’akah, Janoah, Kedesh, Hazor, Gilead, and Galilee—all the land of Naphtali. He exiled them to Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hoshea son of Elah conspired against Pekah son of Remaliah. He struck him down and killed him. Then he became king in his place in the twenty-second year of Jotham son of Uzziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Pekah’s acts and everything he did, you can find them written in the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year of Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel, Jotham son of Uzziah king of Judah became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he ruled for sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jerusha daughter of Zadok.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, like everything that his father Uzziah had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high places were still not removed. The people were still offering sacrifices and burning incense on the high places. He built the upper gate for the House of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of Jotham’s acts, the things he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, the Lord began to send Rezin king of Aram and Pekah son of Remaliah against Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jotham rested with his fathers, and he was buried with his fathers in the city of his father David. Then his son Ahaz became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventeenth year of Pekah son of Remaliah, Ahaz son of Jotham, king of Judah, became king.
speaker: Narrator
